Posts.Content: Did anyone have, or at least consider proton beam radiation? I keep going back and forth between surgery and proton beam. thanks
Posts.Title: What I Wish I Knew Before my Proton Beam Treatments

Posts.Content: Did anyone have, or at least consider proton beam radiation? I keep going back and forth between surgery and proton beam. thanks
Posts.Title: What I Wish I Knew Before my Proton Beam Treatments

Posts.Content: Here's what I know about proton beam: It is extremely expensive ($50,000-$150,000), though Medicaid does cover it. A lot of insurance companies don't. First, they'll surgically implant seeds in your prostate, which they will use to guide the proton beams. Then, you'll get radiated once a day for about 9 weeks. There are NO limits as to what you do during that 9-week period. And there's little if any discomfort during the therapy. The big advantages, to me, are that your chances of leakage are much lower than surgery, and your likelihood of ED is delayed (I've been told anywhere from 6 months to 5 years). The extent of ED is a big unknown for proton beam, which is too bad because it is, to me, a big reason to do it instead of surgery. Guys who have had it seem to swear by it. Unfortunately, there's hardly any good data available on the side effects. And there are none of the other standard surgery risks like, well, death or infection. And no catheter. The biggest disadvantages are that there's no follow-up pathology as there is with surgery, so your PSA test is the only way to know if you are cancer-free. There's also risk of rectal issues, since the tip of the rectum gets radiated in the process. A small percentage (5%, i think, or maybe even less) suffer serious rectal issues that require treatment while more folks suffer temporary stuff like constipation, etc. As with any radiation, there's the slight chance of secondary cancers, which usually develop 8-10 years later, if they develop at all. And, as with any radiation, it makes any prostate surgery difficult, if doable at all, later. Just curious if anyone here has direct experience. thanks

Posts.Title: What I Wish I Knew Before my Proton Beam Treatments

Posts.Content: I'm slated for surgery in a couple of weeks and have probably spent too much time on message boards reading posts from guys with a range of ED-related side effects: no erections, weak erections, decrease in length, decrease in girth, unsatisfactory orgasms. I would love to hear about positive outcomes! Did you have surgery and are now able to get erections close to what you had before surgery? Did you lose little girth or length? Is intercourse still enjoyable? THANKS!
Posts.Title: Sex after surgery -- positive outcomes

Posts.Content: I'm slated for surgery in a couple of weeks and have probably spent too much time on message boards reading posts from guys with a range of ED-related side effects: no erections, weak erections, decrease in length, decrease in girth, unsatisfactory orgasms. I would love to hear about positive outcomes! Did you have surgery and are now able to get erections close to what you had before surgery? Did you lose little girth or length? Is intercourse still enjoyable? THANKS!
Posts.Title: Sex after surgery -- positive outcomes

Posts.Content: Can anyone share HIFU stats? Cure and recurrence rates for Gleason 6 & 7s versus surgery? How often 2nd HIFU is needed? ED rates? Also, do you know whether Ablatherm or Sonablate tends to have more side effects? I believe I was told dthat Sonablate has much better outcomes, but am curious to know from those of you who have had one or the other. thanks
Posts.Title: HIFU stats?

Posts.Content: Fairwind, I did begin reading the HIFU posts, but there seemed to be less stats and much more discussion among just a handful of folks. That, I discussed HIFU with a radiation oncologist who is one of the nicest, most patient and most straight-forward docs I know, and he was really concerned about HIFU side effects and strongly advised me against it. Wish, I think alternative treatments to surgery make perfect sense for someone such as yourself with very small amounts of fairly non-aggressive cancer in just two cores. If I had those kinds of numbers, I'd opt for either AS or a very non-invasive treatment. I am 58 as well. But I have 5 positive cores, including two at 40% and 50%, though mostly 3+3 with a speck of 3+4. But it is just enough volume that AS is not an option. I've gone back and forth with proton beam and recently HIFU but I think I may opt for surgery instead. Thanks for feedback.

Posts.Title: HIFU stats?

Posts.Content: Ralph, Winter, Both of you had just one positive core, with 5% involvement, and T1c, but rapidly rising PSAs. Am I reading that corrrectly? Seems like you both had a small amount of a very non-aggressive cancer. Did you consider active surveillance or some form of radiation or perhaps some other treatment? thanks, slappy 5 of 12 positive cores, T1c, 4.5 PSA, 5%, 10%, 20%, 40% & 50% involvement. No treatment yet.
Posts.Title: 19 Days post DaVinci Surgery - My Update

Posts.Content: While there is much attention, understandably, to sexual function after surgery (and radiation), I don't read or hear much about dry orgasms. Satisfying? Frustrating? Very different? thanks
Posts.Title: Dry Orgasms

Posts.Content: While there is much attention, understandably, to sexual function after surgery (and radiation), I don't read or hear much about dry orgasms. Satisfying? Frustrating? Very different? thanks
Posts.Title: Dry Orgasms

Posts.Content: I am waiting for a third opinion on my biopsy and was told I could hear something this week UNLESS the pathologist needs to order stains. I have no idea what this is, but read that stains are used to distinguish types of cancers. I'm simply trying to verify whether I am 3+3=6 or 3+4=7. When do prostate cancer biopsy pathologists typically order stains? And why? (I am trying to set my expectations to know if I can expect an answer this week or if it likely to get drawn out yet another week or two.) thanks
Posts.Title: When A Pathologist Orders Stains

Posts.Title: 19 Days post DaVinci Surgery - My Update

Also, do you know whether Ablatherm or Sonablate tends to have more side effects? Posts.Title: HIFU stats?

Posts.Content: I am 58 and pretty concerned about post-treatment quality of life, so I've decided to pursue Active Surveillance until circumstances dictate otherwise. My doctor relented even though he points out that 5 of my 12 cores were positive, and one was 50%, both of which are outside of the recommended Johns Hopkins guidelines. I got my biopsy results in May 2013. I had a Gleason Score of 3+3=6, and PSA of 4.5. It was re-tested last week and was 3.9. I even had a Prolaris test, which looks for genetic markers of more aggressive cancers, none of which it determined that I had (I am not sure I'd bet the ranch on this test, but it does support my AS strategy, regardless of its reliability.) I was comfortable with the decision -- the odds are very high that something other than prostate cancer will kill me, and I'll take those odds if I can avoid those possible nasty side effects. Here's the monkey wrench. Last week, I got the results of a second opinion on my biopsy from University of Pennsylvania Hospital. They said they detected 3+4=7 in one of my five positive cores. They suggested I get Dr. Epstein's opinion at Johns Hopkins as the tie-breaking interpretation, and I may do that, but regardless of his interpretation, I'll always know at least one pathologist thinks my prostate cancer is a little more serious than the initial biopsy reading. So I'm just not sure if Active Surveillance is still the way to go. Appreciate any suggestions or insights. Thanks
Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: It was quite a surprise to me how unable urologists are to predict the likelihood that prostate cancer will spread beyond the prostate. A biopsy can suggest that a cancer is widespread and aggressive, but isn't nearly as effective at telling you if you are among the vast majority of people with prostate cancer who have a slow-growing cancer that you can outlive. Thanks, all, for your insights. That second, revised opinion was a real kick in the gut. After weeks of consultations, tests and soul-searching, I'd finally gotten comfortable with Active Surveillance, but now I feel like I'm starting the process all over again. If my real Gleason score is 3+4, I guess I should be thankful someone spotted it.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: I am 58 and pretty concerned about post-treatment quality of life, so I've decided to pursue Active Surveillance until circumstances dictate otherwise. My doctor relented even though he points out that 5 of my 12 cores were positive, and one was 50%, both of which are outside of the recommended Johns Hopkins guidelines. I got my biopsy results in May 2013. I had a Gleason Score of 3+3=6, and PSA of 4.5. It was re-tested last week and was 3.9. I even had a Prolaris test, which looks for genetic markers of more aggressive cancers, none of which it determined that I had (I am not sure I'd bet the ranch on this test, but it does support my AS strategy, regardless of its reliability.) I was comfortable with the decision -- the odds are very high that something other than prostate cancer will kill me, and I'll take those odds if I can avoid those possible nasty side effects. Here's the monkey wrench. Last week, I got the results of a second opinion on my biopsy from University of Pennsylvania Hospital. They said they detected 3+4=7 in one of my five positive cores. They suggested I get Dr. Epstein's opinion at Johns Hopkins as the tie-breaking interpretation, and I may do that, but regardless of his interpretation, I'll always know at least one pathologist thinks my prostate cancer is a little more serious than the initial biopsy reading. So I'm just not sure if Active Surveillance is still the way to go. Appreciate any suggestions or insights. Thanks

Posts.Content: It was quite a surprise to me how unable urologists are to predict the likelihood that prostate cancer will spread beyond the prostate. A biopsy can suggest that a cancer is widespread and aggressive, but isn't nearly as effective at telling you if you are among the vast majority of people with prostate cancer who have a slow-growing cancer that you can outlive. Thanks, all, for your insights. That second, revised opinion was a real kick in the gut. After weeks of consultations, tests and soul-searching, I'd finally gotten comfortable with Active Surveillance, but now I feel like I'm starting the process all over again. If my real Gleason score is 3+4, I guess I should be thankful someone spotted it.
Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: I am 58 and pretty concerned about post-treatment quality of life, so I've decided to pursue Active Surveillance until circumstances dictate otherwise. My doctor relented even though he points out that 5 of my 12 cores were positive, and one was 50%, both of which are outside of the recommended Johns Hopkins guidelines. I got my biopsy results in May 2013. I had a Gleason Score of 3+3=6, and PSA of 4.5. It was re-tested last week and was 3.9. I even had a Prolaris test, which looks for genetic markers of more aggressive cancers, none of which it determined that I had (I am not sure I'd bet the ranch on this test, but it does support my AS strategy, regardless of its reliability.) I was comfortable with the decision -- the odds are very high that something other than prostate cancer will kill me, and I'll take those odds if I can avoid those possible nasty side effects. Here's the monkey wrench. Last week, I got the results of a second opinion on my biopsy from University of Pennsylvania Hospital. They said they detected 3+4=7 in one of my five positive cores. They suggested I get Dr. Epstein's opinion at Johns Hopkins as the tie-breaking interpretation, and I may do that, but regardless of his interpretation, I'll always know at least one pathologist thinks my prostate cancer is a little more serious than the initial biopsy reading. So I'm just not sure if Active Surveillance is still the way to go. Appreciate any suggestions or insights. Thanks

They suggested I get Dr. Epstein's opinion at Johns Hopkins as the tie-breaking interpretation, and I may do that, but regardless of his interpretation, I'll always know at least one pathologist thinks my prostate cancer is a little more serious than the initial biopsy reading. So I'm just not sure if Active Surveillance is still the way to go. Appreciate any suggestions or insights. Thanks
Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: I am 58 and pretty concerned about post-treatment quality of life, so I've decided to pursue Active Surveillance until circumstances dictate otherwise. My doctor relented even though he points out that 5 of my 12 cores were positive, and one was 50%, both of which are outside of the recommended Johns Hopkins guidelines. I got my biopsy results in May 2013. I had a Gleason Score of 3+3=6, and PSA of 4.5. It was re-tested last week and was 3.9. I even had a Prolaris test, which looks for genetic markers of more aggressive cancers, none of which it determined that I had (I am not sure I'd bet the ranch on this test, but it does support my AS strategy, regardless of its reliability.) I was comfortable with the decision -- the odds are very high that something other than prostate cancer will kill me, and I'll take those odds if I can avoid those possible nasty side effects. Here's the monkey wrench. Last week, I got the results of a second opinion on my biopsy from University of Pennsylvania Hospital. They said they detected 3+4=7 in one of my five positive cores. They suggested I get Dr. Epstein's opinion at Johns Hopkins as the tie-breaking interpretation, and I may do that, but regardless of his interpretation, I'll always know at least one pathologist thinks my prostate cancer is a little more serious than the initial biopsy reading. So I'm just not sure if Active Surveillance is still the way to go. Appreciate any suggestions or insights. Thanks
Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: It was quite a surprise to me how unable urologists are to predict the likelihood that prostate cancer will spread beyond the prostate. A biopsy can suggest that a cancer is widespread and aggressive, but isn't nearly as effective at telling you if you are among the vast majority of people with prostate cancer who have a slow-growing cancer that you can outlive. Thanks, all, for your insights. That second, revised opinion was a real kick in the gut. After weeks of consultations, tests and soul-searching, I'd finally gotten comfortable with Active Surveillance, but now I feel like I'm starting the process all over again. If my real Gleason score is 3+4, I guess I should be thankful someone spotted it.

I got my biopsy results in May 2013. I had a Gleason Score of 3+3=6, and PSA of 4.5. It was re-tested last week and was 3.9. I even had a Prolaris test, which looks for genetic markers of more aggressive cancers, none of which it determined that I had (I am not sure I'd bet the ranch on this test, but it does support my AS strategy, regardless of its reliability.) I was comfortable with the decision -- the odds are very high that something other than prostate cancer will kill me, and I'll take those odds if I can avoid those possible nasty side effects. So I'm just not sure if Active Surveillance is still the way to go. Appreciate any suggestions or insights. Thanks

A biopsy can suggest that a cancer is widespread and aggressive, but isn't nearly as effective at telling you if you are among the vast majority of people with prostate cancer who have a slow-growing cancer that you can outlive. Thanks, all, for your insights. That second, revised opinion was a real kick in the gut. After weeks of consultations, tests and soul-searching, I'd finally gotten comfortable with Active Surveillance, but now I feel like I'm starting the process all over again.
